thread.title: Five thoughts: Sloppy play paces Tech to fifth-straight loss against Baylor
thread.title_full: Five thoughts: Sloppy play paces Texas Tech to fifth-straight loss against Baylor | Dallas Morning News

author: Mike DuPont
title: Five thoughts: Sloppy play paces Tech to fifth-straight loss against Baylor
text:
Click here to view the box score
The Red Raiders maintained a 15-game winning streak against the Bears prior to 2011. However, No. 5 Baylor achieved its fifth victory in as many seasons with a 63-35 win against Texas Tech in Arlington.
Here are five thoughts from Texas Tech's loss.
1. Second quarter separation
Texas Tech trailed by double-digits when the quarter started but Baylor's run in the second quarter put the Bears ahead comfortably and allowed them to take a 49-28 lead into halftime. Sophomore quarterback Patrick Mahomes managed to locate freshman Tony Brown Jr. on a 13-yard touchdown pass, but three of Texas Tech's four other possessions ended with turnovers. Shock Linwood put the Bears ahead 35-14 on an eight-yard run following a fumble by senior DeAndre Washington. Garland native Seth Russell continued to pile on with a 16-yard touchdown pass to junior receiver and Richardson-Pearce graduate Corey Coleman following an interception from Mahomes.
2. Turnovers
Despite passing for 415 yards and three touchdowns, Mahomes did toss a pair of interceptions in the loss. Mahomes threw into coverage in the second quarter and Xavien Howard made the most of his opportunity with a 46-yard interception return. Baylor responded with a 16-yard touchdown. Travon Blanchard also intercepted Mahomes in the third quarter. A fumble by DeAndre Washington was answered with an 8-yard rushing touchdown from Shock Linwood. The Bears scored 14 points off turnovers.
3. Penalties
Texas Tech appeared to be a more disciplined team before facing Baylor. The Red Raiders were the Big 12's most penalized team in 2014 - trailed by the Bears - and transformed into the least penalized Big 12 team of 2015 through the first four games. Texas Tech received 21 penalty flags in its first four games this season. Against Baylor, Kliff Kingsbury's bunch was penalized nine times in the first half alone, finishing with 17 penalties for 142 yards. The Red Raiders don't need a perfect game against the Cyclones, but Texas Tech will need to focus its disciplinary efforts before next weekend's matchup against Iowa State.
4. Extending the play
The status of Texas Tech's quarterback was an uncertainty beyond the team's facilities and Mahomes continued to display the ability to improvise and extend plays that helped him earn the starting role. In the team's opening possession, Mahomes escaped the pocket and found sophomore receiver Zach Austin on a 55-yard touchdown pass. It was Austin's first catch of his career and he finished as the Red Raiders' leading receiver with eight catches for 110 yards.
5. Fast starts continue
After scoring a touchdown in their opening possession against the Bears, the Red Raiders have scored a touchdown on four of five opening drives this season. A struggle to maintain offensive balance ultimately derailed Texas Tech's chances before halftime. The Red Raiders rushed for 14 total yards in the first quarter, gaining one first down on the ground. Tech's rushing attack finished with 106 yards on 24 carries with one touchdown - a 25-yard run by Mahomes.
Baylor 63, Texas Tech 35: Complete coverage
